1.rationale:
Let’s re‐examine the current board and our options. Our snake’s head is currently at (2,3) and we want to grab the closest apple at (1,2).

From (2,3) we have four adjacent moves:
• UP to (2,4) – that moves away from the apple.
• RIGHT to (3,3) – also moves away.
• LEFT to (1,3) – this would put us one step directly above the apple (since (1,2) is just below).
• DOWN to (2,2) – this would place us one step to the right of the apple.

Both LEFT and DOWN reduce the Manhattan distance to (1,2) down to 1 (|1–1|+|3–2| if LEFT, or |2–1|+|2–2| if DOWN). There are no obstacles in either direction: the board shows no snake parts or walls blocking either (1,3) or (2,2).

I’ll opt to head DOWN from (2,3) – moving to (2,2) – because it is a direct decrease in the vertical coordinate and then, on the following move, I can easily go LEFT into the apple at (1,2). This keeps our path simple and short without any risk near enemy snake #2 or running into walls.

My strategy for the next turn after moving DOWN is to then move LEFT from (2,2) to reach and collect the apple at (1,2). This will guarantee growth and points while keeping the maneuver straightforward.

Decided next move: DOWN.
